grafting aluminium and zirconium alkoxides and related sulphates on silica P. Iengoa, M. Di Serioa, A. Sorrentinoa, V. Solinasb, E. Santacesariaa'* a Dipartimento di Chimica dell'Universit?t di Napoli, via Mezzocannone 4, 80134 Naples, Italy t, Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiehe, Via Ospedale 72, 09124 Cagliari, Italy Received 4 July 1997; received in revised form 3 October 1997; accepted 7 October 1997 Abstract In this paper we will show that it is possible to modify the acid properties of a surface, rich of hydroxyl groups by grafting in suitable conditions metal alkoxides, such as aluminium and zirconium alkoxide. Depending on the amount of metal alkoxide it is possible to obtain, after steaming of the surface and calcination, different coverage degree up to the monolayer. Iteration of the grafting technique gives a multilayer, completely modifying the original surface. Grafting aluminium and zirconium alkoxides pre-treated in homogeneous phase with pure sulphuric acid leads to catalysts with very strong acid sites on the surface. The acidic properties of the catalysts obtained by grafting aluminium and zirconium alkoxides and their sulphate derivatives on silica have been characterized by different techniques such as: potentiometric titrations, Temperature Programmed Desorption of organic bases and differential calorimetry to evaluate the density of the active sites and their strength. Prepared catalysts were proven in test reactions such as methanol dehydration and hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking. We have shown that sulphated catalysts have very strong acid sites of both the Brrnsted and Lewis type, able to promote hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking at the relatively low temperature of 250)C. ~; 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords." Acid catalyst; Grafting alkoxide; Sulfated alkoxide 1. Introduction Some papers have been published recently dealing with the preparation of catalysts obtained by grafting metal alkoxides on the surface hydroxy groups of different carriers, in particular, a group of papers *Corresponding author. Tel. +39 81 5476544; fax +39 81 5527771 ; e-mail: santacesaria@chemna.dichi.unina.it describes grafting of vanadyl triisopropoxide on oxi- des such as ZrO2, TiO2, SiO2 [1-3] to obtain catalysts with better redox properties. Another group of papers describe the interaction of titanium alkoxides with surface hydroxyls on silica [4,5] with the aim of obtaining a high dispersion of titanium on the surface. At last, we found only two cases in which grafting alkoxides had the aim of modifying the acidity of a surface [6,7] by reacting tetraethoxysilane with the 0926-860X/98/$19.00 ,~(" 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(97)00303-7 86 P. lengo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 167 (1998) 85-101 surface hydroxyls on alumina. On the contrary, dif- ferent papers have been published on the impregnation of silica in aqueous solution with alumina precursors [8]. By considering the large availability of different alkoxides, at present, the lack of papers on this subject in literature is surprising and, in spite of the easily recognizable potential advantages and versatility of the surface modifications obtained with this technique, the argument has not yet deepened enough. As a matter of fact, it is possible to modify surfaces rich of hydroxyls by grafting alkoxides: with low coverage degree to obtain, after steaming of the surface and calcination, a high dispersion of the corresponding oxide or isolated acid sites of particular strength; with a monolayer, by completely altering the nature of the original surface as to the density of the hydroxyls and the kind of acidity; with multilayers, by repeating the treatments of steaming and calcination after each grafting opera- tion, to obtain a solid with a chemically different surface but retaining the original mechanical and structural properties; it is also possible, before grafting, to opportunely modify the available alkoxide to make it volatile, when we want to perform a gas-solid phase opera- tion, or soluble in aprotic solvents, if we want a liquid-solid phase reaction, or, at last, it is possible to introduce by reaction another compound in the alkoxide molecule to obtain bifunctionality or superacidity. In the present work and in subsequent notes, we will study many of the mentioned possibilities of grafting alkoxides and derivatives on the most common car- riers. In particular, in this note, the preparation and properties of catalysts obtained by grafting with dif- ferent coverage degree aluminium and zirconium alkoxides and their sulphate derivatives on the silica surface will be studied. The catalysts obtained were examined with electrochemical techniques to evaluate the density of the hydroxyls the ZPC (Zero Point Charge) and the intrinsic surface ionization constants. The same catalysts were subjected to TPD (Tempera- ture Programmed Desorption) analysis with two dif- ferent organic bases to determine the semiquantitative distribution of acid sites, and some samples were also submitted to the microcalorimetric analysis using pyridine as probe molecule. Finally, catalysts were tested in two different reactions: the methanol dehy- dration, which is normally promoted by the acid sites of low or medium strength, and the n-hexane isomer- ization and cracking, which is favoured by strong acidic sites. 2. Experimental 2.1. Apparatus, methods and reagents 2.1.1. Preparation of catalysts Catalysts were prepared by contacting a silica sup- port with specific area of about 280mZ/g with an alkoxide solution in toluene. Commercially available aluminium isopropoxide is readily soluble in toluene and can, therefore, be used directly after purification. Purification was made by dispersing hydroxylated insoluble aluminium in benzene and filtering it. Ben- zene is then eliminated by vaporization. Zirconium alkoxide in the form of a solution of tetra-n-butoxide (80%) in n-butanol (20%) was submitted to the exchange reaction with 1-octanol: Zr(OC4H9)4 -- 4CH3(CH2)vOH --+ Zr(OCsH17)4 + 4C4H9OH ~" (I) The reaction was performed at 140 by distilling off both the n-butanol originally contained in the solution and formed during the reaction. Zirconium octanoxide is a white solid readily soluble in toluene which can, therefore, be used in this form for grafting purposes. Sulphate derivatives of both aluminium and zirconium alkoxides were then prepared as described elsewhere [9,10] by adding pure sulphuric acid (100% by weight), drop by drop, to the alkoxide solution in toluene at room temperature. The following reaction occurs: M(OR),, + H2SO4 --~ M(OR),~_2SO4 + 2ROH (2) and the products obtained are described in detail in previous works of Di Serio et al. [9,10]. Silica used for grafting was previously calcined at 500 for about 2 h. Weighed amounts of silica were put in 100 cm3 of the alkoxide solution and kept at 110 for 6 h by refluxing toluene and stirring the slurry. The reactions occurring can be schemed in a simplified way as follows: P. lengo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 167 (1998) 85-101 87 Me(OR)n-1 + ROH OH + Me(OR)n toluene (3) OH + Me(OR)n ~ 7 toluene OH (4) ~ OH + Me(OR)m-2SO4 b OMe(OR)m-3SO4 + ROH (5) After reaction, the solid obtained was recovered by filtration, washed with toluene, dried, put in a fixed bed and steamed at 150, in the case of aluminium, and 190cc in the case of zirconium. Hydrolysis was prolonged for about 2 h. Then, steamed catalysts were discharged and calcined at 500 for 2 h with the exception of zirconia sulphated catalyst calcined at 400 for 3 h to avoid decomposition of the sulphate group occurring in the range 450-500. The zirco- nium sulphate catalysts were red or brown like the corresponding precursor in homogeneous solution. Zirconium sulphate catalysts prepared in this way seems, therefore, to be quite different from the ones prepared with the classical way reported by the lit- erature because they are coloured and much sensitive to the temperature. 2.1.2. Determination of the amounts of metal anchored on the support The amounts of aluminium grafted on silica were determined by dissolving weighed quantities of the solid samples with an aqueous solution of KOH and analyzing the solutions obtained by atomic absorption spectrometry at 309.3 nm. Grafted zirconium was determined by dissolving it with 6 M HC1 kept in contact with the solid for 24 h. A known amount of the solution obtained was then treated with Xylenol Orange forming a red-orange complex having a maximum light absorption at 535 nm [11]. Zirco- nium-treated samples were, therefore, analyzed spectrophotometrically. Sulphur in the samples treated with sulphuric acid does not interfere in both cases. 2.2. Catalysts characterization, techniques employed Catalysts were characterized by using different techniques such as potentiometry, TGA (Thermo Gravimetric Analysis), TPD (Temperature Pro- grammed Desorption) using two different organic bases such as pyridine and 2,6-dimethylpyridine, and microcalorimetry, by pyridine adsorption. The performances of the catalysts prepared were tested by measuring their activities in the dehydration of methanol for the grafted alkoxides and in the n-hexane isomerization and cracking for the grafted sulphate alkoxides. The potentiometric characterization consists in titrating 50 cm3 of a slightly acidic (pHi3) solution of NaCI 0.1 M additioned with HC1, with NaOH 0.1 M or, on the contrary, a basic solution of NaOH (pH~ 10) with HC1 0.1 M, respectively in the presence or in the absence of a weighed amount of a solid catalyst. In Fig. 1 (c), pKa values are reported as a function of the surface charge to determine the intrinsic ionization constants by extrapolation at the ZPC. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on both the carrier and all the catalysts prepared to evaluate the number of hydroxyls released for dehy- dration between 500 and 1000. This number was then compared with the corresponding value obtained from potentiometric measurements. TPD (Temperature Programmed Desorption) runs were performed by previously saturating a weighed sample of the catalyst with an organic base such as pyridine (Fluka, Milan, Italy, 98% purity) or 2,6- dimethylpyridine (Fluka, Milan, Italy, 98% purity) at temperatures 15-20 higher than the boiling point of the corresponding base. Helium was used as a carrier gas with flow rates ranging between 6 and 10 cm3/min, and a TCD as detector. Then, temperature was increased with a scanning rate of 10/min up to 170 and kept isothermal for about 2 h. In this way, physically adsorbed molecules of the different bases were completely released. After this pretreatment, temperature was again increased with a scanning rate of 10/rain up to 420 and kept isothermal for the time necessary to obtain a negligible release of the chemically adsorbed base. As the area of the peaks obtained from chromatograms resulted proportional to the amount of organic base injected, it is possible to evaluate the chromatographic factor and, conse- quently, to determine the amount of base released at each temperature. We have used two different bases because, as reported by Benesi [ 14], 2,6-dimethylpyr- P. lengo et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 167 (1998) 85-101 89 idine is almost selectively adsorbed on Br6nsted sites, while pyridine reacts with both Br6nsted and Lewis sites of high and medium strength. We observed that more acid sulphate catalysts does not completely release the organic bases, at 420'~C but we avoided increasing this temperature to prevent the occurrence of sulphate decomposition. However, these runs had the main scope to show the change of acid-base properties occurring on the surface as a consequence of grafting the alkoxides. Calorimetric runs were performed on samples of about 80 mg preliminarly kept at 400 for 12 h at 2.0.10-8 atm. The adsorption isotherms were carried out in a Tian-Calvet calorimeter of the Setaram using pyridine as probe molecule. Different known amounts of pyridine were added to the catalysts until a pressure of 1.2-10 3 atm was reached. Then, the samples were outgassed at 150 for 12 h and a second adsorption isotherm was run up to the same final pressure. The difference between both isotherms is the amount of irreversibly adsorbed pyridine, From the calorimetric data, the integral and differential adsorption heats, the number of sites and their distribution according to the adsorption energies can be determined. The performances of the catalysts were tested, as mentioned before, by measuring the activities shown respectively in the dehydration of methanol in the case of grafted alkoxides, characterized by acidity of med- ium and low strength, and by n-hexane isomerization and cracking reactions in the case of grafted sulphate alkoxides, characterized by the presence of strong acidic sites on their surface. Activity tests were per- formed in both cases in a stainless steel tubular reactor of 0.5 i.d. operating in isothermal conditions. A syringe pump was used for feeding the liquid reagents in both cases. Helium was used as a diluent and carrier gas in the case of methanol dehydration, nitrogen in the case of n-hexane isomerization and cracking. A sampling valve, kept at 150, allows the on line analysis of the products and of the residual reagent in both cases. Methanol dehydration was performed at about 180~C in the presence of 1-2 g of catalyst by using a methanol feed rate of 1.05 cm3/h while the helium flow rate was 300 cm3/h. As the obtained conversions were lower than 5%, the reactor can be considered as a differential one and the initial reaction rates can be easily determined. Reaction products and the residual reagent were analyzed using an HP 5890A gas-chromatograph equipped with a capillary column of 0.53 mm i.d. containing Carbowax 20 M as sta- tionary phase and TCD as detector. The column was heated at a scanning rate of 180/h from 50 to 60C and then kept isothermal at this temperature. The Helium head column pressure was 2 atm. Some kinetic runs were also performed by feeding pyridine dissolved in methanol for poisoning the catalysts and evaluating the number of active sites in the reaction conditions, n-hexane isomerization and cracking reac- tions were studied applying about 1 g of aluminium or zirconium alkoxide sulphate at different temperatures of, respectively, 250, 300 and 400~C, with a flow rate of 0.5 cm3/h of liquid n-hexane and 90 cm3/h of nitrogen. The analyses were performed by an HP 5890A gas-chromatograph equipped with a FID detec- tor and a capillary column of Poraplot 25 M 0.32 mm i.d. n-hexane, n-pentane, 2-methylpentane (2MP), 3- methylpentane (3MP) and methylcyclopentane (MCP) were recognized using samples of pure com- pounds furnished by Fluka (Milan, Italy). Other hydrocarbons were identified and determined with the aid of Kovats indexes [15]. The data obtained were interpreted by considering the reactor operating in differential conditions, the overall conversions obtained being lower than 5%. Results and discussion 3.1. Determination of the surface properties of the catalysts prepared by potentiometric titrations and TGA The catalysts prepared by grafting on silica, with the already described technique, aluminium isoprop- oxide, zirconium octanoxide, and related sulphate derivatives are summarized in Table 1. In all cases, alkoxides in a toluene solution are not quantitatively adsorbed on the surface and an adsorp- tion equilibrium seems to be operative. Therefore, in order to obtain a greater degree of surface coverage, more concentrated alkoxide solu- tions must be used. As it can be seen, by increasing the aluminium isopropoxide concentration in toluene from 2.6 to 28 g/dm3, an increase in adsorbed aluminium from 0.07 to 2.1 mmol/g is obtained. in this way we prepared three catalysts (Ca~, C~2, Cm~) differing only in the amount of aluminium anchoring on the surface. The catalyst named Cml corresponds to a solid obtained by saturating the surface with an amount of aluminium corresponding to about a monolayer. Cm2 has been obtained by hydrolyzing Cml with steam and by contacting again the solid obtained with aluminium isopropoxide dissolved in toluene. By repeating steaming and grafting on Cm2, we obtained Cm3; to conclude, Cruz and Cm3 correspond to the multilayer adsorptions of aluminium oxide on silica. Cas is a catalyst obtained by grafting sulphate aluminium isopropoxide. Zirconium octanoxide and the related sulphate are less reactive than aluminium as it can be seen by the amount adsorbed in the preparation of Czl and Czs catalysts, still reported in Table 1 together with the conditions adopted for grafting. All the catalysts of Table 1 were submitted to electrochemical characterization to evaluate the hydroxyl densities, the ZPC and the surface intrinsic ionization constants, K1 and K2. The results obtained are reported in Table 2. The same table also shows, for comparison pur- poses, the values obtained for the silica support used (280 m2/g), for a commercial 7-alumina (180 m2/g) and a commercial silica-alumina obtained by co-pre- cipitation (alumina was 13,6% by weight, the specific surface area was 140 m2/g). All the catalysts were also submitted to TGA to determine the water release in the range between 500 and 1000. The hydroxyl den- sities determined by this method are also reported in Table 2 for comparison purposes. From the data reported in Table 2 we can observe, first of all, that grafted alumina on the silica surface abruptly changes the properties of the surface, as expected. In fact, the values of pK1 and pK2 strongly increase and sample Cml shows values quite similar to those found for silica-alumina obtained by co-precipitation. The PZC values gradually change and the value obtained for the sample Cm3, characterized by a multi- layer deposition of alumina on the silica surface, is comparable with that of 7-alumina. For this sample, we obtained a pKi value similar to those observed for the samples containing less aluminium on the surface while, on the contrary, pK2 is again comparable to that obtained for alumina. As to grafted zirconium, the amount of this element anchored on the surface probably is small to change the properties of the surface and, as it will be seen, great differences appeared only in the acid properties determined by activity in the catalytic reaction tests. 3.4. Determination of acid surface properties by TPD All the prepared catalysts were submitted to TPD after the adsorption of different organic bases, as already described in a previous section, with the aim to show the effect of grafting alkoxides on the acid-base properties of silica support. This effect can be well appreciated by observing Figs. 3 and 4. In Fig. 3 the results obtained for the catalyst Ca1, Ca2, CmI,C~I and the corresponding support SiO2, by using pyridine as a base, are reported. In Fig. 4 the beha- viours of Cal, Ca2, Cml and Czl in the presence of the base 2,6-dimethylpyridine are compared. As it can be seen, in both cases, the presence of the alumina on the silica surface strongly increases the acidity of both the Br6nsted and Lewis type sites. A semiquantitative estimation of the number of acid sites can be derived from TPD plots such as the ones reported in Figs. 3 and 4. The obtained results are summarized in Table 3. We considered, in this table, three classes of acid sites depending on the desorption range temperature: weak acid sites (T<250), inter- mediate acid sites (250<T<400) and strong acid sites (T>400). The number of sites reported in Table 3 is underestimated in the case of C,,s and Czs catalysts because, the final temperature of 420 is too low to completely remove the organic bases. In fact, the overall number of acid sites determined for C~,~ appears in Table 3 to be lower than the one determined for Cml. On the contrary, the situation is reversed in the case of calorimetric analyses, as it will be seen in the next section. Another evidence of the presence of strong acid sites not revealed by TPD is the activity shown by Ca~ and Cz~ in the reaction of n-hexane isomerization and cracking. Conclusions To conclude, in the present work we have shown the possibility to anchor on the surface of a support rich in hydroxyl groups, such as the silica support, different amounts of aluminium and zirconium alkoxides chan- ging the acidic properties of the surface. The catalysts 100 P. lengo et al./Applied 6?ttalvsis A: General 167 (1998) 85-101 obtained are not completely similar to those obtained by co-precipitation, and their preparations are char- acterized by greater flexibility. We have also shown that it is possible to completely change the surface of a support turning, for example, from silica to alumina or zirconia, by repeating more times the operation of grafting the alkoxide and steaming the surface. The support obtained with a completely modified surface retains mechanical and morphological properties. Finally, we have shown that, by reacting both alumi- nium and zirconium alkoxides with pure sulphuric acid (100%) in homogeneous phase and by anchoring the originated alkoxide sulphate on silica, very strong acid catalysts are obtained. These catalysts are able to promote hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking at the relatively low temperature of 250. Preparation and properties of new acid catalysts obtained by grafting alkoxides and derivatives on the most common supports note I — grafting aluminium and zirconium alkoxides and related sulphates on silica P. Iengo a M. Di Serio a A. Sorrentino a V. Solinas b E. Santacesaria * a a Dipartimento di Chimica dell'Universitàdi Napoli, via Mezzocannone 4, 80134 Naples, Italy b Dipartimento di Scienze Chimiche, Via Ospedale 72, 09124 Cagliari, Italy * Corresponding author. Tel. +39 81 5476544; fax +39 81 5527771 In this paper we will show that it is possible to modify the acid properties of a surface, rich of hydroxyl groups by grafting in suitable conditions metal alkoxides, such as aluminium and zirconium alkoxide. Depending on the amount of metal alkoxide it is possible to obtain, after steaming of the surface and calcination, different coverage degree up to the monolayer. Iteration of the grafting technique gives a multilayer, completely modifying the orginal surface. Grafting aluminium and zirconium alkoxides pre-treated in homogeneous phase with pure sulphuric acid leads to catalysts with very strong acid sites on the surface. The acidic properties of the catalysts obtained by grafting aluminium and zirconium alkoxides and their sulphate derivatives on silica have been characterized by different techniques such as: potentiometric titrations, Temperature Programmed Desorption of organic bases and differential calorimetry to evaluate the density of the active sites and their strength. Prepared catalysts were proven in test reactions such as methanol dehydration and hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking. We have shown that sulphated catalysts have very strong acid sites of both the Brönsted and Lewis type, able to promote hydrocarbon isomerization and cracking at the relatively low temperature of 250°C.
